title: Belarusian Prisoners Go Free After US Helps
summary: In Belarus, 123 people who were in prison for speaking out against the government have been released. They include famous protest leaders like Maria Kolesnikova, who smiled and hugged others in a happy video. Another person, Viktor Babaryka, who wanted to be president, was also freed. These people were put in jail because they opposed the leader Alexander Lukashenko, who used force to stop big protests in 2020. The United States helped by talking to Belarus and lifting some sanctions, which are punishments that stop trade. This made Lukashenko happy because he can now talk to the US again. The US might be doing this to improve relations with Russia, since Belarus is a friend of Russia. The prisoners are joyful but remember others still in jail.

keywords.explanation: people who are kept in jail
when people gather to show they disagree with something
punishments from other countries that stop trade or travel
the group that runs a country
a big country that helped in the talks

questions.question: How many prisoners were released in Belarus?
Why were these people put in jail?
Which country helped in the negotiations?
What did the US lift to help Belarus?
What did the prisoners feel when they were freed?

background_read: Belarus is a country in Europe with a leader named Alexander Lukashenko. In 2020, many people protested against him because they wanted more freedom, but the government used force to stop them. Some protesters were put in jail as political prisoners. The United States and other countries sometimes use sanctions, which are like penalties, to pressure governments to change. Recently, the US talked to Belarus and removed some sanctions, leading to the release of these prisoners. This shows how countries can work together to help people in trouble.
Article_Structure: WHO: Belarusian political prisoners, including Maria Kolesnikova and Viktor Babaryka, and the US government.
WHAT: 123 prisoners were released after negotiations led by the US, which lifted sanctions on Belarus.
WHERE: Belarus, a country in Europe.
WHY: The prisoners were jailed for opposing the government, and the US engaged to improve relations, possibly with Russia.

perspectives.description: The released prisoners feel happy and hopeful, but remember others still in jail.
